## Natural history notes

The Pinewoods Fingergrass (Eustachys petraea) is a perennial bunchgrass native to the Caribbean, Central America, South America, and extending into southern Florida. It grows in sandy, coastal, and rocky soils, often in open pinelands, dunes, and disturbed ground. Its dense tufts help reduce soil erosion in dry, sandy landscapes. The epithet petraea means “rocky,” reflecting its tendency to grow in thin, stony or sandy soils.
